data.text: Can't Decide: Nemo Dragonfly 2P or Big Agnes Copper Spur HVUL 2
I’m looking to upgrade my tent but not sure which one to get. I have two choices. Nemo Dragonfly 2P or Big Agnes Copper Spur HVUL 2. I would prefer a 2P tent. Any thoughts?

I have the dragonfly 2p. Seems great. I have thought maybe the other one you mention or tigerwall if they're any more versatile. It's a bit to set up all the stakes . I wonder if the copper spur packs down smaller?
data.author: Aaron Wissler

data.text: some review said that dragon fly isn’t water proof. Any truth?
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: it was pretty dry when I've used it. I've brought it home to dry but not any problem inside I've noticed. The tiny zippers can be snagged if you don't zip properly.
data.author: Aaron Wissler

data.text: I'd think the tent dwr or what you call it would be easy to spray on.
data.author: Aaron Wissler

data.text: I’m a pretty big guy (6’3” 235 lb) and love my Copper Spur 2p. Awesome tent.
data.author: Sid de Haan

data.text: I’m 5’10” with the Tigerwall UL2 and it feels short sometimes. The Copper Spur is only 2” longer. Maybe the walls are more vertical. I still like it though for solo use.
data.author: Tim Davis

data.text: my copper spur came yesterday. I set up and it seems to be be really nice.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: The Copper Spur is so amazingly easy to setup and I love it! I’ve always heard that Nemo had issues with rain leaking in. I could be wrong. I love my Copper Spur though
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I read about the rain leaking too.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: do you have the bikepacking version?
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: Just the regular version. I just pack it in to my trailer. I don’t use bags, at least not currently. But either way, the tent itself would be the same. Other than the bag having holders for the bike.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I’m leaning on getting this. Thank you.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: I don’t regret it at all. I can set the whole thing up in 3 minutes. I’d also recommend getting the groundsheet meant for that tent. Has multiple uses!
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: it is free standing right?
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: ground sheet will let you fast pitch and save weight too. Not to be used in buggy conditions obviously but makes the tent itself feel much roomier.
data.author: Tom Lanier

data.text: and Big Agnes will replace/repair any manufacture defect issues.
data.author: Tom Lanier

data.text: I have the Fly Creek HV UL2 and it friggin rocks. Love it!
data.author: Adam Mertz

data.text: Have copper spur three man for wife and I. Love the tent and the extra room.Was stuck in the tent during a twelve hour downpour and stayed comfortable and dry
data.author: Gary McClintock

data.text: Flycreek 2p bike packing version. In my opinion it’s a good fit for one person plus gear. Two person would be tight.
data.author: Tim Doyle

data.text: No experience with either tent. But I have looked into both. I dig the Big Agnes packing system for their tights. Very convenient
data.author: Carl Cruz

data.text: Both are well regarded brands. For me, ease of setup, ease of getting in/out, a good amount of ventilation, and weight are important factors.
data.author: Matthew Wilson

data.text: MSR Hubba Hubba nx1 or 2 for me
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: I’m looking for bikepacking specific with shorter poles.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: been using both for bikepacking for 6 years pole sets are short enough to go either on front role elastic if you have ortleib or in your frame bag...i have a pretty big bike. either is light enough in my opinion 2 person is more comfy and great for 2...nx 1 is wicked light but pretty small.
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: yah I’ve had 1 person tent but looking to get 2P. I need more room.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: yeah definitely more comfy...the msr is one of a few with a single pole and is very speedy and easy for single person setup....its also freestanding which in IMO is critical
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: agreed. I just finished a week bikepacking, I wish that I had free standing tent.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: nice...where were you riding?
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: Pittsburgh to DC
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: well done
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: Our big Agnes served us well for many years. We upgraded to the big agnes tiger wall and it seems very flimsy snd light but so far so good
data.author: Lisa Smith

data.text: You can get the Dragonfly on Moosejaw with their 20% coupon and Big Agnes is on Moosejaw today for 25% off. Both are well reviewed tents on multiple outdoor websites. For example see the reviews on Outdoor Gear Lab. I decided against both for reliability issues that I found on multiple user reviews. Dragonfly had broken pole issues and Copper spur had fabric tear issues. I am going with the Durston X-Mid 2 when it comes back in stock for price, weight, quality. I have a SixMoons Lunar Solo which I love but it is single wall and I need something for humid climates.
data.author: Shawn Christiansen

data.text: I have been super happy with my BA Copper Spur. I use it for both backpacking and bikepacking.
data.author: Patty Cartwright

data.text: The copper spur is a wonderful tent. Don’t gave experience with the dragonfly to compare these.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: Been using the midori solo and love it. Very light.
data.author: Andrew Rivas

data.text: oooh that does look nice
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: it has a fly and a huge vestibule.
data.author: Andrew Rivas

data.text: vestibule is critical in the PNW...i have the msr hubba hubba nx1...big vestibule as well.
data.author: Patrick Martin

data.text: I use the dragonfly 2p, but it is very tight… it is good for 1p and gear.
data.author: John Pannell

data.text: I had the Copper Spur 2 and loved the room as I'm tall however, I found it too big and luxurious for remote solo bikepacking. If you have resupply close by or there are not many hikabike/Mtn passes it would be a great choice........for bike touring :)
data.author: Todd McMurray

data.text: Pair your tent with the sleep system
data.author: Aaron Wissler

data.text: I will be using the Big Agnes for a week straight, next week, I'll give you a review when I'm done
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: Thr Big Agnes. Great tent used it in all weather through my CT hike, bikepacking trips, and everything in between. Has never let me down.
data.author: Albert Leary

data.text: Update: I ordered the Big Agnes Copper Spur 2P.
data.author: William Petrie

data.text: I got the big Agnes .. super happy with it !! I debated between those 2 as well
data.author: Christophe Lautrette

data.text: Updat3: got the Big Agnes 2P and it fit amazingly in my handle bar.
data.author: William Petrie
